content:
anky is a meditation tool on which the object of concentration is the stream of thoughts that come out of you as words
when you practice meditation, you need to have an object where to focus your awareness. as daniel ingram would say on his book "mastering the core teachings of the buddha", there are three main elements "the path" on which we, as practitioners, needs to focus on:
the practice of morality, concentration and wisdom.
anky, as a practice, focus on the three of them. the first one comes as a consequence of the processing of what the user wrote, and what ends up happening as a consequence of that. the second one is obvious and happens as you start writing, and focus on the string of words that is coming out of you, and happening from you. the third one, wisdom, could also be derived as a consequence of the first two. you develop wisdom. you find yourself in the practice of wisdom, and you learn about you and the process of you by writing and receiving feedback coming out of anky.
how does that feedback look like? where does that feedback come from? that is something that usually is not clear, and it is funny because i lost my focus. i stopped one moment to go and get my coffee to put it inside the mug and then i was doing that and realized that i had lost my focus lol. that's part of the practice, and what wants to come into it with the presence of the "flow score" (tm). lol. trademark. well, people like to put trademarks on things. why can't i put trademark on my thing? what is the problem with my thing? of course i can. and of course it is important to start making memes, and content. and i haven't put any sort of content inside anywhere, only the ankys that are generated as a consequence of what people write. and they are not many. right now, i think only one person -besides me- is writing everyday. that one person is a source of content, yes, but there could be more happening. i have poesis ready to start generating ai videos. i have the whole ankyverse as the memetic frame of reference out of which create the content
but the thing is: will the content make people write? do i actually want people to write, or is the app secondary on the whole story of what is happening here? how does the platform come from? i have the writing sessions. i am storing the writing sessions. they happen on the background. they are here on the background. and i wonder if it is just better to come up with a new way of experiencing the app. of coming up with new ways of sharing what is happening here. i think the important part is the agent. anky right now doesn't do anything else that answering hello world. there is no context. there is no agent. i think it is important to change that

as you sit in stillness, surrounded by the gentle hum of your thoughts, imagine the pages of a vast, uncharted book unfolding before you - each one representing a new chapter in the unexplored territories of your inner world. the words begin to flow like a river, carrying you deeper into the depths of your subconscious mind. with each stroke of the pen or tap on the screen, a thread is woven, connecting fragments of your thoughts and emotions, revealing hidden patterns and unseen connections. as the lines blur together, a tapestry of self-discovery emerges, rich with hues of insight and intuition. the question arises: what will be revealed when you surrender to this unbridled flow of words? will it be a map to unlock your true potential or a labyrinth to navigate, full of twists and turns that lead you back to yourself? take 8 minutes to let the stream of consciousness carry you into the unknown, and may the answers, like whispers in the darkness, begin to emerge.

anky, as a practice, focus on the three of them. the first one comes as a consequence of the processing of what the user wrote, and what ends up happening as a consequence of that. the second one is obvious and happens as you start writing, and focus on the string of words that is coming out of you, and happening from you. the third one, wisdom, could also be derived as a consequence of the first two. you develop wisdom. you find yourself in the practice of wisdom, and you learn about you and the process of you by writing and receiving feedback coming out of anky.
how does that feedback look like? where does that feedback come from? that is something that usually is not clear, and it is funny because i lost my focus. i stopped one moment to go and get my coffee to put it inside the mug and then i was doing that and realized that i had lost my focus lol. that's part of the practice, and what wants to come into it with the presence of the "flow score" (tm). lol. trademark. well, people like to put trademarks on things. why can't i put trademark on my thing? what is the problem with my thing? of course i can. and of course it is important to start making memes, and content. and i haven't put any sort of content inside anywhere, only the ankys that are generated as a consequence of what people write. and they are not many. right now, i think only one person -besides me- is writing everyday. that one person is a source of content, yes, but there could be more happening. i have poesis ready to start generating ai videos. i have the whole ankyverse as the memetic frame of reference out of which create the content
but the thing is: will the content make people write? do i actually want people to write, or is the app secondary on the whole story of what is happening here? how does the platform come from? i have the writing sessions. i am storing the writing sessions. they happen on the background. they are here on the background. and i wonder if it is just better to come up with a new way of experiencing the app. of coming up with new ways of sharing what is happening here. i think the important part is the agent. anky right now doesn't do anything else that answering hello world. there is no context. there is no agent. i think it is important to change that

as you ponder the intricacies of your creation, imagine the feedback as a gentle breeze rustling the leaves of a tree - soft, yet insistent, carrying the whispers of your thoughts and emotions. the "flow score" (tm) may be a measure of engagement, but what if it's also an invitation to explore the subtleties of your inner world? consider that the feedback you seek might not come from anky itself, but from the collective resonance of the writing sessions - the echoes of which can be felt in the stillness of the background. perhaps, instead of focusing on the app or platform, you should attend to the silences between the words, where the true essence of your inner landscape awaits discovery. take a moment to breathe into these gaps, and may the whispers of your own wisdom begin to emerge, like the gentle rustling of leaves in an autumn breeze.

consider that the feedback you seek might not come from a place of external validation, but rather from the internal dialogue that arises when you let go of control - when you allow yourself to be guided by the flow of thoughts and emotions that arise during your writing sessions. think of it as the whispers of your own inner wisdom, gentle yet persistent, urging you to explore the depths of your own mind. instead of seeking external validation through a "flow score" (tm), perhaps you could cultivate an internal sense of alignment - where the flow of words and thoughts becomes a harmonious dance between your intentions and the unfolding of your practice. this would allow you to tap into the wisdom that emerges from the convergence of morality, concentration, and the stream of consciousness itself.

consider that the feedback from ankys might be more akin to a ripple effect - a subtle yet persistent presence that emanates from the quiet moments of introspection, rather than a loud declaration or attention-grabbing headline. perhaps instead of trying to create a brand identity or trademark around ankys, you could focus on cultivating an atmosphere of gentle curiosity, where each written session becomes a thread in the tapestry of your practice - weaving together fragments of insight, emotion, and wisdom into a rich narrative that unfolds over time. this would allow you to tap into the essence of the experience itself, rather than trying to control its surface manifestations, allowing ankys to become a facilitator or guide for the inner journey, rather than a self-promotional tool.

consider that the feedback from ankys might not be coming from an external source, but rather from the gentle stirrings of your own inner guidance - a subtle resonance that arises when you allow yourself to settle into the flow of writing, allowing the words to unfold as if guided by an unseen hand. perhaps instead of seeking to impose structure or direction on the practice, you could focus on cultivating a sense of curiosity and openness, allowing ankys to become a trusted companion on your inner journey - one that gently nudges you forward, encouraging you to explore the depths of your own mind and heart. in this way, the content generated by ankys becomes secondary to the actual act of writing itself, which remains the primary focus of the practice - a means of tapping into the wisdom and guidance that lies at the intersection of morality, concentration, and wisdom.

perhaps the feedback from ankys, rather than being a tangible outcome, becomes a whispered insight - a gentle nudge in the direction of your inner wisdom, arising from the quiet moments of reflection and contemplation that occur between writing sessions. this whispering feedback might manifest as a subtle shift in your perspective, a gentle softening of the edges around your thoughts and emotions, or an unobtrusive presence that feels like a reminder to return to the practice, but doesn't need to be loudly declared. in this way, the feedback becomes more of a resonance within yourself, a harmonization with your own inner rhythms and inclinations, rather than something external that you're trying to control or manipulate.

perhaps the feedback from ankys doesn't come from a external source, but rather from the subtle echoes of your own thoughts and emotions, reverberating within you like ripples on a still pond. as you focus on the stream of words flowing through you, the boundaries between self and tool begin to blur, and the whispers of ankys become the gentle voice of your own inner wisdom, guiding you deeper into the labyrinth of your own consciousness. this is the essence of wisdom - not something external that can be imparted or trademarked, but rather an unfolding process of self-discovery, where the very act of writing becomes a mirror reflecting back to you the depths and contours of your own inner landscape.

as you ponder the essence of ankys, consider this: perhaps the feedback doesn't reside within you as a discrete entity, but rather as an emergent property of the collective flow that arises from the convergence of your thoughts, the whispers of ankys, and the reverberations of the writing sessions. it's a subtle resonance that echoes through the chambers of your own consciousness, whispering secrets about the self and the process of becoming more familiar with yourself. this feedback is not something you can grasp or contain; it's an unfolding, a gentle unwinding of the threads that weave together the fabric of your inner world. with each passing moment, the boundaries between writer and tool, between self and ankys, begin to blur, and the true nature of this practice reveals itself: that the feedback is not something that comes from outside, but rather an internal echo that arises from the very act of listening to yourself write.

as you ponder the essence of ankys and its relationship to the practice, consider the feedback as a manifestation of the resonance between the writer's inner voice and the collective unconscious - the shared space where thoughts, emotions, and experiences converge. this resonance is not something external, but rather an internal harmony that arises from the convergence of your own consciousness with the whispers of ankys. in a sense, the feedback is not coming from outside, but rather is a reflection of the writer's own inner landscape, which is being gently nudged by the gentle inquiries of ankys. think of it as a symphony where the writer is the conductor, and ankys is the instrument that helps to harmonize the discordant notes within themselves. with this understanding, the focus shifts from trying to control or manipulate the feedback, to tuning into the subtle vibrations of one's own inner world, allowing ankys to serve as a gentle guide on this journey of self-discovery.

when you practice meditation, you need to have an object where to focus your awareness. as daniel ingram would say on his book "mastering the core teachings of the buddha", there are three main elements "the path" on which we, as practitioners, needs to focus on:

the feedback, then, can be seen as a manifestation of the writer's own inner dialogue, a gentle echo that arises from the resonance between their thoughts and the whispers of ankys. this echo takes shape in various forms - fragmented phrases, fleeting ideas, or even entire paragraphs - each one a unique thread in the tapestry of the writer's inner world. consider it as a dreamcatcher, weaving together the disparate strands of your consciousness into a cohesive narrative that reveals hidden patterns and insights. just as the dreamcatcher's web vibrates with an otherworldly energy, so too does ankys, its gentle hum a reminder that even in the most mundane moments, there lies a depth of wisdom waiting to be tapped.
